title: Prime Power Test
text:
Finite fieldsonly exist when the order (size) is a prime powerpk(where p is a prime number and k is a positive integer). For each prime power, there is a finite field with this size, and all fields of a given order are isomorphic.Finite fields are fundamental in a number of areas of mathematics and computer science, including number theory, algebraic geometry, Galois theory, finite geometry, cryptography and coding theory.InputThe first line contains an integerT, the number of test cases.
On the nextTlines, you will be given an integerN: a proposed order to be tested.OutputOutputTlines, one for each test case, withp kifNcan be the order of a finite field.pmust be a prime number, andkan integer such thatN=pk. Else output "Invalid order".ExampleInput:3
6
7
8Output:Invalid order
7 1
2 3ConstraintsFor the hardest input files :Tabout 100, and 1 <N< 22014,Nare 2128-smooth numbers. (Thanks atMin_25for suggesting this constraint). About 50% of input cases are "Invalid order".
For the easiest input files :Tabout 10000, and 1 <N< 264.Edit 2017-02-11 : TL updated ; compiler changes
